label: 217. William Henry Heyward to John P. Meau -- September 24, 1864
description: Letter from William Henry Heyward to John P. Meau concerning the assessment for the Confederate Tax of 1864.  Letter includes an exhaustive inventory of slaves, acreage, types of crops, etc., for several Heyward plantations including Fife, Myrtle Grove, Rotterdam and Hamburgh.  On one unnamed Heyward plantation in St. Peter's Parish, William Henry Heyward writes, "in consequence of the proximity of the enemy the greater portion of this land has been abandoned."  4p. September 24, 1864.

On one unnamed Heyward plantation in St. Peter's Parish, William Henry Heyward writes, "in consequence of the proximity of the enemy the greater portion of this land has been abandoned."  4p. September 24, 1864.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Columbia Sept 24th 1864.  Mr Jno. P. [illegible]  Dear Sir,  We enclose you our Return for the Confed. Assessor. We are not able to complete it as to the number and ages of the negroes and the plantation Tools.   We suppose you know how to give a list of the negroes and their ages. You must say how many up to 12 years, how many up to 50 years, and how many up to 70. and the number over 70 years.  When you complete your paper for the Return you had better ask Messr R. Habersham where and when it is to be returned. They may be willing to make the Return for us.  You must find out from the Asessor the amount that we will owe them- what is due now and let us know. Ask him if we cant put the amount to their credit here in Columbia in the Bank of the State of So.Ca. You can ask Mr Habersham also about this. If Mr Habersham will make the Return, you have only to complete the paper we send you- and give it to [End Page 1] Messr. Habersham.   You can tell Messr. Habersham that we are provided with our 4 per cent Certificate to pay the Tax.  Yours respectfully  Wm H Heyward.      [upside down:]   Agricultural Land 30,600 Negroes [$44.00?] [illegible] 250.  Plantation utensils &c 50. Thrasher &c 1000  66.3.00  36.3.35  102.6.35   5  5.1.3175    Land 31575.  Slaves 2400.  Grain 1860  Furniture 500  36335 [End Page 2] Jas. B. Heyward Land in St. Bartholomew's Parish South Carolina    Hamburg  260 acres of 2d quality Rice land  470  "    3d " " "  140 " Provision land    20 " in Pastures Settlement &c  938  1828     [illegible]  242 acres wooded land, inferior fire wood   Sowers Land  100 acres Old Field   Price Land  232 acres Pine Land  574   Rotterdam  100 acres 2d quality Rice Land   90 "  3d " " "  197 "  worthless land  387  Myrtle Grove  100 acres 2d quality Rice Land  200 "  3d " " "   70 "  good corn land & Settlement  375 "  wooded land  346 "  Pine Land cleared of all good timber  229 "  worthless Land  1320    Planted 1864  331 acres in Rice   46 "  in Corn   20 "  Potatoes   20 "  Peas  417 "  in all [End Page 3] Return of the joint property of James B. and Wm Henry Heyward in St Peter's Parish So. Carolina- for the Confed. Tax 1864.  1126 Acres of Land as follows.    371 acres 2d quality Rice land   248 "  3d " " "  128 "  swamps & bogs  379 "  Second growth Pine land    In consequence of the proximity of the enemy the greater portion of this land has been abandoned and remains uncultivated- most of the negroes having been removed. These are cultivated this year as follows  280 Acres in Rice   30 "  in Provisions  There were on hand 17th February 1864  1800 Bushels of Rice & 60 Bushels Corn.     There are between 50 & 60 Negroes to be returned by the Overseer according to age.    Furniture, Crockery, glass &c. worth $500. [End Page 4]
